title: RBA moves but government holding the line until May budget
text:
In the good old days, when interest rates cuts were a political positive, the government of the day – ie, the Howard government – would always brag about how much an average homeowner would save on their mortgage.

On Tuesday, after the RBA cut rates for the third time this year, leaving the cash rate at a record low 0.75 per cent, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stoically ignored the indictment on the state of the economy and went back to the well instead.

Josh Frydenberg has ignored the rate cut's indictment on the state of the economy. AAP

"What this means for an Australian family with a mortgage of $400,000 is $720 less a year in interest payments. That's a significant benefit to an Australian family,'' he said.

That may have been the case if the banks passed the latest cut on in full – which they did not – and if people even noticed it. Rates are so low, many are already using the opportunity to reduce the principal by paying more than the minimum repayment.

The rate cuts are not having as much effect as they do when rates are higher.
description: The government is trying to protect the promised surplus for 2019-20 while hoping current policy settings will start turning the ship around.
